text: Section 420 of the Indian Penal Code defines cheating as fraudulent inducement to deliver property. The punishment includes imprisonment up to seven years and fine. This section applies when someone dishonestly induces another person to deliver any property or make any alteration to destroy the whole or any part of a will or security. The Supreme Court has held that cheating requires deception and fraudulent inducement as essential ingredients.

The Indian Evidence Act of 1872 governs the admissibility of evidence in judicial proceedings. Section 3 defines relevant facts as facts that are connected to the facts in issue. The Act establishes rules for oral evidence, documentary evidence, and expert testimony. Evidence must be relevant and legally obtained to be admissible in court. The burden of proof generally lies on the party who asserts a fact.

The Code of Criminal Procedure 1973 provides the procedural framework for criminal trials in India. It outlines the process from investigation to trial and appeal. The Code includes provisions for arrest, bail, search and seizure, and trial procedures. It ensures fair trial rights for the accused while maintaining public order and justice. The Supreme Court has interpreted many provisions to protect constitutional rights.

Article 21 of the Indian Constitution guarantees the right to life and personal liberty. This fundamental right cannot be deprived except according to procedure established by law. The Supreme Court has expanded this right to include various aspects like right to privacy, right to health, and right to clean environment. This article forms the basis for many human rights protections in India.

The doctrine of basic structure limits Parliament's power to amend the Constitution. The Supreme Court established this doctrine in the Kesavananda Bharati case. Certain basic features cannot be destroyed through constitutional amendments. These include federalism, secularism, democracy, and judicial review. This doctrine maintains the Constitution's essential character and fundamental principles.

Section 302 of the Indian Penal Code prescribes punishment for murder. The offense is punishable with death or life imprisonment and fine. The courts consider aggravating and mitigating circumstances before imposing the death penalty. The Supreme Court has established strict guidelines for death penalty cases to prevent arbitrary application. Life imprisonment is the default punishment unless rarest of rare cases are established.

The Indian Contract Act of 1872 governs contractual relationships in India. It defines what constitutes a valid contract including offer, acceptance, consideration, and free consent. The Act provides remedies for breach of contract including damages and specific performance. It distinguishes between void and voidable agreements. The Act forms the foundation of commercial law in India.

The Supreme Court of India is the apex judicial body in the country. It has original jurisdiction in disputes between states and fundamental rights cases. It hears appeals from High Courts and can grant special leave to appeal. The Court's decisions are binding on all other courts in India. It plays a crucial role in interpreting the Constitution and protecting fundamental rights.

Section 498A of the Indian Penal Code addresses cruelty against married women. It punishes husband or relatives of husband who subject the woman to cruelty. The punishment includes imprisonment up to three years and fine. The Supreme Court has issued guidelines to prevent misuse of this provision while protecting genuine victims. The section aims to prevent domestic violence and protect married women.

The principle of res judicata prevents re-litigation of already decided matters. Once a court has finally decided a case, the same parties cannot relitigate the same issue. This principle ensures finality of judgments and judicial efficiency. The doctrine applies when the matter is directly and substantially in issue in the former suit. It promotes legal certainty and prevents multiple litigation.

The doctrine of stare decisis ensures consistency in judicial decisions. Lower courts are bound by decisions of higher courts. This principle creates a hierarchy of precedents that must be followed. The Supreme Court's decisions are binding on all courts in India. High Courts are bound by Supreme Court decisions but not by each other. This doctrine ensures uniformity in law application.

The law has been amended several times to strengthen protections. The Supreme Court has issued guidelines for speedy trial of rape cases. The section aims to protect women's dignity and bodily autonomy.

The principle of natural justice forms the foundation of administrative law. It includes rules against bias and right to be heard. These principles ensure fair decision-making by administrative authorities. Violation of natural justice can invalidate administrative actions. The Supreme Court has expanded these principles to protect individual rights against arbitrary state action.

The concept of public interest litigation allows citizens to approach courts on behalf of others. PILs can be filed when public interest is affected even if the petitioner is not directly affected. The Supreme Court has liberalized PIL rules to promote social justice. PILs have been instrumental in environmental protection, human rights, and governance issues. They strengthen access to justice for marginalized communities.

The doctrine of separation of powers divides government authority among legislative, executive, and judicial branches. Each branch has distinct functions and checks on others. This principle prevents concentration of power and protects democracy. The Indian Constitution establishes this separation though not rigidly. The judiciary interprets laws while the legislature makes them and the executive implements them.
